subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] QS-SAMPA: a proposed format for plain-text Quickscript
msgSnippet: First off, creating a new keyboard layout is easy. I m most familiar with Ukelele, for Mac OS X:
messageBody:
First off, creating a new keyboard layout is easy. I'm most familiar
with Ukelele, for Mac OS X:
http://scripts.sil.org/cms/scripts/page.php?site_id=nrsi&item_id=ukelele

Once you've installed different layouts, on the Mac you can switch
between them with a keyboard command--I don't know if it's as easy on
Windows or Linux, but it certainly should be!

I haven't used any of the Windows keyboard layout tools, but I know
that there are many options, for example:
http://www.microsoft.com/globaldev/tools/msklc.mspx
http://www.tavultesoft.com/

I haven't done this on Linux either, but the open-source KMFL project
looks good:
http://kmfl.sourceforge.net/

Certainly if you use many different computers you'll either have to
learn more than one keyboard layout (I do this already, switching
between Qwerty and Dvorak layouts as needed) or become proficient at
installing new keyboard layouts on each OS you use frequently. That's
not practical, obviously, when you're just checking email in your
local public library, but are we going to type long texts in QS in the
public library?

Optimizing a layout necessarily involves many quirks of individual
preference, so of course we need a layout that will be usable for most
people without any customization. I happen to think the present layout
is bad, and that this proposal based on X-SAMPA is a huge improvement.

Ted


On Dec 1, 2007 9:57 AM, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
> >
> >
> > Hi Moira,
> >
> > There are two separate issues here:
> > 1) A standard ASCII representation of QS would (a) facilitate online
> > discussion and (b) provide an easy way to exchange QS documents in
> > plain text.
> > 2) Any individual can create a personal keyboard layout to optimize
> > typing effort and/or mnemonic functions of key assignments. (For
> > example, I greatly increased my typing speed when I switched from the
> > Qwerty to the Dvorak keyboard layout. It took a few months to reach
> > full speed, but it was well worth it.)
> >
>
> But what happens when you are not at your own computer, which happens
> quite a bit to me? Then you can't rely on the special keyboard layout
> you created. Plus, creating keyboard layouts sounds like a big pain in
> the butt. Every time I installed a new system, I'd have to install the
> new keyboard layout before I could type QS, and using different keyboard
> layouts for different platforms might further complicate things to the
> point of wanting to smash a few keys. And I assume I'd have to switch
> between layouts for when I wanted to type QS and when I wanted to type
> TO. For better or worse, we are going to be stuck to this new standard,
> so we should make sure it makes sense for all users, not just those who
> are comfortable with SAMPA.
>
> I also hope we are not loosing sight of QS. We should be able to think
> and write in QS directly. If we are going to spend so much of our time
> looking at the ASCII representations of QS, I wonder if we haven't
> defeated ourselves.
>
> Paul
>
